0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• one unit of C1 inhibitor, human is equal to the mean C1 inhibitor quantity in 1 mL of normal human plasma
  • Hereditary angioedema, Abdominal, facial, or laryngeal attacks: Berinert(R): 20 units/kg slow IV injection at a rate of approximately 4 mL/min
  • Hereditary angioedema; Prophylaxis: Cinryze(R): 1000 units IV infusion over 10 minutes every 3 to 4 days

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and efficacy of Berinert(R) not established in children 12 years of age and younger
  • safety and efficacy of Cinryze(R) have not been established in neonates, infants, or children
  • one unit of C1 inhibitor, human is equal to the mean C1 inhibitor quantity in 1 mL of normal human plasma
  • Hereditary angioedema, Abdominal, facial, or laryngeal attacks: (greater than 12 years of age) Berinert(R): 20 units/kg slow IV injection at a rate of approximately 4 mL/min
  • Hereditary angioedema; Prophylaxis: (adolescents) Cinryze(R): 1000 units IV infusion over 10 minutes every 3 to 4 days

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Hereditary angioedema, Abdominal, facial, or laryngeal attacks
  • Hereditary angioedema; Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction - Emergency CABG

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity reactions, life-threatening (eg, anaphylaxis), to human C1 esterase inhibitors

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity reactions (eg, hives, tightness of chest, wheezing, hypotension, and anaphylaxis) may occur during or after injection; exercise caution for treatment choice as symptoms may be similar to hereditary angioedema; epinephrine should be immediately available for acute hypersensitivity
  • self-administration; due to risk of airway obstruction during acute laryngeal hereditary angioedema attacks, immediate medical attention is recommended in addition to self-administration of drug
  • thrombotic events have been reported; monitoring recommended in patients with risk factors for thrombosis
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash (3.5% to 10%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (1.8% to 18%), Taste sense altered (4.7%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (7% to 28%)
  • Respiratory:Sinusitis (5% or greater), Upper respiratory infection (1.8% or greater)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Deep venous thrombosis, Myocardial infarction
  • Hematologic:Thrombosis of blood vessel
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary embolism

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The primary function of C1 inhibitor is to regulate the activation of the complement and intrinsic coagulation (contact system) pathway. C1 inhibitor also regulates the fibrinolytic system. It is hypothesized that increased vascular permeability and the clinical manifestation of hereditary angioedema attacks are primarily mediated through contact system activation. Suppression of contact system activation by C1 inhibitor through the inactivation of plasma kallikrein and factor XIIa is thought to modulate this vascular permeability by preventing the generation of bradykinin.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • (Berinert(R)) allow vial and diluent to come to room temperature prior to reconstitution
  • (Berinert(R)) reconstitute with 10 mL of provided diluent (sterile water for injection) via provided transfer set (Mix2Vial(TM)) or other commercially available double-ended needle and vented filter spike; push spike at blue end of MIX2Vial(TM) transfer set firmly through center of diluent stopper; invert the diluent vial and push the spike into the Berinert(R) vial; vacuum in product vial will draw in diluent
  • (Berinert(R)) gently swirl vial and diluent while still attached to transfer set; do not shake vial
  • (Berinert(R)) remove transfer set and withdraw appropriate dose from vial with syringe; multiple vials may be pooled in a single syringe; use separate transfer set for each vial
  • (Berinert(R)) do not refrigerate or freeze after reconstitution; store solution at room temperature (25 degrees C or 77 degrees F) and use within 8 hours
  • (Berinert(R)) final concentration after reconstitution is 50 units/mL
  • (Berinert(R)) administer reconstituted solution by slow IV injection at a rate of 4 mL/min
  • (Berinert(R)) do not mix with other medications and administer through a separate infusion line
  • (Cinryze(R)) allow vial to come to room temperature, before or after reconstitution and prior to administration
  • (Cinryze(R)) two vials are required for 1 total dose
  • (Cinryze(R)) reconstitute with 5 mL of sterile water for injection via a transfer needle to a concentration of 100 units/mL; vacuum in product vial will draw in diluent; do not use if no vacuum is evident
  • (Cinryze(R)) gently swirl vial until all product is reconstituted
  • (Cinryze(R)) product must be administered at room temperature no later than 3 hours after reconstitution; discard unused portion
  • (Cinryze(R)) administer reconstituted solution IV at an initial infusion rate of 1 mL/min over 10 minutes

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduction in number, severity, and duration of swelling attacks associated with hereditary angioedema is indicative of efficacy
  • signs and symptoms of thrombosis; in patients with known risk factors.
  • symptoms of hypersensitivity during or after infusion

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Berinert
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 500 U
  • Cinryze
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 500 U

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient who self-administers the drug to seek immediate medical attention in an appropriate healthcare facility following drug administration for an acute laryngeal attack or suspected abdominal attack.
  • Despite screening and testing, human plasma products carry a risk of transmitting infectious agents. Risks and benefits should be discussed with patient by healthcare professional.
  • Drug may cause dysgeusia, upper respiratory tract infections, sinusitis, rash, and headache.
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of allergic hypersensitivity reactions (eg, hives, urticaria, tightness of the chest, wheezing, hypotension, and/or anaphylaxis).
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of thrombosis (eg, new-onset limb or abdomen swelling and pain, new-onset chest pain, shortness of breath, loss of sensation or motor power, or altered consciousness, vision, or speech).
